content.question: Which of the following correctly compares the strength of the two carbon-to-carbon bonds in the molecule represented in the Lewis diagram shown above?

choices.label: The carbon-to-carbon bond on the left is stronger because it is a double bond.

The carbon-to-carbon bonds are the same strength because the <math alttext="C C C" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>C-C-C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> bond angle is <math alttext="180 degrees" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>180</mn><mi>Â°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>.
The carbon-to-carbon bonds are the same strength because they are both bonds between carbon atoms.
The carbon-to-carbon bond on the right is stronger because there are more hydrogen atoms attached to the rightmost carbon atom than to the leftmost carbon atom.

content.answer: The carbon-to-carbon bond on the left is stronger because it is a double bond.

skill.text: 6.C: Support a claim with evidence from representations or models at the particulate level, such as the structure of atoms and/or molecules.
